Abstract: The advent of DNA-editing enzymes as base editors has revolutionized the field of genetic engineering, offering unprecedented precision in the modification of nucleic acids. This research delves into the design and application of these enzymes, focusing on the roles of deaminases, methyltransferases, demethylases, and glycosylases in the targeted alteration of DNA bases. Through advanced protein engineering techniques, these enzymes have been optimized for enhanced specificity, efficiency, and reduced off-target effects, enabling their application in a wide range of genetic contexts. The study highlights the potential of base editors in therapeutic interventions, agricultural improvements, and the elucidation of genetic mechanisms, underscoring their significance in advancing our understanding and manipulation of the genetic code. This abstract encapsulates the cutting-edge developments in the field, presenting a comprehensive overview of the current state and future prospects of DNA-editing enzymes as base editors.
